title: Teachers in fight with head filmed chanting 'she's getting sacked in the morning' in Bowdon | Metro News
text:
Georgia Diebelius for Metro.co.uk Tuesday 28 Feb 2017 10:47 am The teachers were filmed chanting (Picture: MEN) 
A group of alleged teachers at the centre of a battle with their boss were caught on camera chanting: ‘She’s getting sacked in the morning!’. 
Shot on a mobile phone, the clip appears to show the staff and some parents toasting each other at an out of hours gathering at Bollin Primary School in Bowdon on Friday. Doctors create term for pain Syrian children experience because it’s far worse than PTSD 
The jubilant group were reportedly chanting about headteacher Michelle Brindle, who is at the centre of several complaints over her leadership. 
The ongoing row involving school leaders, staff and parents, culminated with the school being closed with immediate effect at lunchtime yesterday. 
Parents were contacted to collect their children and say they haven’t been told when the school will open again. To view this video please enable JavaScript, and consider upgrading to a web browser that supports HTML5 video Headmistress Michelle Brindle at war with her own staff (Picture: Cavendish Press) The video emerged this week (Picture: MEN) 
Before the video was filmed, staff had filed a total of 16 grievances in the last five months. 
The row reached a head this week when teachers staged a strike and protested alongside 70 parents outside the school. 
Teachers captured in the video are understood to have been celebrating an apparent victory in their battle against the leadership at Bollin. 
And it appears that those at the party believed Mrs Brindle was being ousted. 
But the council said that the headteacher had definitely not been sacked or suspended and was still in post. The village primary school was closed yesterday (Picture: Google Maps) Parents were also allegedly present (Picture: MEN) 
An investigation into the video and the circumstances surrounding the footage has been launched by the council, a spokesman said. 
Parents have been divided by the contents of the video. 
One described it as ‘an orderly celebration following a difficult few months’ at the school. 
Another, who asked not to be identified, said she was ‘disgusted’ by the video and its contents. 
The parent said: ‘I am absolutely disgusted and ashamed by it, and now we are having to suffer for the consequences.’ More
